title: Studying in Germany - German B1+
description:
####Learning objectives
The course is aimed at learners who consider studying in Germany and/or want to gain knowledge about academic culture in Germany and deepen their language skills in written and oral activities. All learning material will be available in the Moodle course.  
Upon successfully engaging in this course, learners:
- Can follow much of everyday conversation and discussion, provided it is clearly articulated in standard language or in a familiar variety.
- Can navigate typical situations in an academic context (read and answer formal correspondance, find strategies to follow a lecture in their own field, find information about different types of classes and their requirements, identify formal and informal language and adapt their own language according to different settings with teachers or fellow students, etc.)

####Details of the learning scenario
This offer is **mixed**: weekly video meetings via Zoom (focusing on oral activities) connected with asynchronous individual learning through Moodle (learning videos, exercises and quizzes, writing assignments).
The minimum technical requirements you need to participate are a Zoom account, camera and microphone and a stable internet connection.

####Schedule/Timetable of the learning offer
Starting: 30/05/2024 
End: 01/08/2024
Weekly video meetings (Zoom): Thursdays, weekly, 16:30 - 18:30 h 

####Certificate
Certificate of attendance, after minimum participation (Zoom meetings and Moodle activities) of 70 %.

title: My Culture and Yours: A Workshop Exploring Our Thinking, Languages, and Identity
description:
#### Learning objectives

”My Culture and Yours: A Workshop Exploring Our Thinking, Languages, and Identity” is a pilot project hosted by the language centers of the University of Potsdam and Tel Aviv University—respectively the Center for Language and Key Competences (Zessko) and Center for Language Excellence (CLE)—to create a COIL version of a language café. Extending the invitation to partake in the workshop to the language centers and students of the EDUC partner universities of the University of Potsdam, Zessko and CLE offer a three-session COIL in which students will get the chance to explore their own definition of culture, reflect on their own language and cultural background, practice communicating in English, and become acquainted with the new cultures and stories from their fellow participants. These themes will be mediated in story-telling and predominantly oral activities. In this virtual learning setting, students enhance their language proficiency in English as well as their intercultural communicative competence and are asked 1) to  embrace the opportunities that come with experiencing cultural diversity and 2) to then answer the overarching core question of this workshop about one’s own cultural identity; 3) to respect individual difference and shared global values, and 4) to ultimately rise to the EDUC’s mission statement of creating an inclusive and diverse digital space for intercultural exchange and discourse.

#### Details of the learning scenario

This learning offer is **virtual**, and **synchronous**.

Please consider a total work-load of: 4.5 hours (participation EDUC Certificate)

title: Cross-Cultural Communication
description:
#### Learning objectives

Using English as a Lingua Franca (in the case of this course British English is used) as the language of instruction, this course aims to explore perceptions and cultures through the lens of intercultural communication in the context of Europe. Through reflection and study, you will learn how to better identify communication breakdowns and develop new strategies to overcome them in international contexts. This means that this course does not focus on language learning. In this approach, language learning happens naturally as you progress through the course content regarding Cross-Cultural Communication. 

At the end of the course, you will:
- improve your ability to communicate with partners and peers from different cultures as well as your competence in the target language and increase your confidence.
- improve your soft skills (presentation and public speaking) in the target language. 
- have an opportunity to develop and foster international relationships with other EDUC partners.

#### Details of the learning scenario

This learning offer is asynchronous. To succeed in this online component, you need the following:
- B1 level in English
- To participate in the reflective activities
- To utilize online language resources (that you have found helpful in your experiences and / or the ones provided to you in the Introductory Manuel)
- Time
- Understand that this is an INDIVIDUAL study course and will not result in an official certification of language level

Please consider a work-load of: 30 hours

The minimum technical requirements you need to participate are: e.g.: good Internet connection and your university account to log in to [EDUC Moodle](https://learning.educalliance.eu/)

Starting: 15/05/2024
End: 15/11/2026

title: Financing Research
description:
The lecture summarizes the principles of financing research in the academic sector. The lecturer introduces the participants to the most significant national and international programmes for financing research and give them orientation in appropriate financing mix at specific career stages.  The lecture then presents standard principles used in the evaluation of funding applications, basic evaluation criteria, and tips on what style of writing to use to impress the evaluators.

#### Target group

This training activity is intended primarily for PhD students, but can be interesting also for postdocs or junior/senior researchers.

#### Learning objectives

By the end of this course, participants will be able to identify key national and international research funding opportunities and select appropriate financing strategies for different career stages. They will also develop skills to effectively evaluate funding criteria and craft compelling grant proposals tailored to impress evaluators.

title: Communicating Science: Basic Rules and Useful Tools
description:
In the lecture, the lecturer introduces you to the concept of science communication as an integral part of any research. She discusses the formal aspects of science communication, as well as target groups and various formats. She will give you tips on starting to communicate your research right away to your peers, together with useful tools. She will also explain how to reach broader audiences outside your professional field. The lecturer will give you an overview of the institutional role in science communication and show a few examples of Masaryk University's successful science communicators. 

#### Target group

This training activity is intended primarily for PhD students, but can be interesting also for postdocs or junior/senior researchers.

#### Learning objectives

By the end of this course, participants will acquire foundational skills in science communication, including targeting specific audiences and using effective tools to share their research. They will also learn to design communication strategies that broaden their reach beyond academia, leveraging institutional resources and successful examples for inspiration.

description:
During the lecture we will briefly introduce different forms of research evaluation, especially with regard to the current evaluation methodology in the Czech Republic and the impact of evaluation in the scientific environment and scientific publishing.
We will discuss in more detail bibliometrics as a supporting tool for science evaluation and other possibilities of its use, especially for the development of publication strategies. The aim of the lecture will be to present good practice in scientific publishing and working with bibliometric indicators.

#### Target group

This training activity is intended primarily for PhD students, but can be interesting also for postdocs or junior/senior researchers.

#### Learning objectives

After completion of this course, participants will gain knowledge of contemporary research evaluation methods, including bibliometric tools and their implications for publication strategies. They will also learn best practices for scientific publishing and ethical considerations in evaluating research impact.

title: Research Infrastructures
description:
Research infrastructures are usually the result of collaboration between researchers. On the one hand, a scientist as an individual cannot know all the current practices and trends in their field, nor can everyone be equipped with state-of-the-art technology costing tens of millions of crowns, which they would then not use properly if they had it only for themselves. The purpose of research infrastructures is therefore to make scientific work more efficient, even from an economic point of view.
And how do the Czech Republic and Masaryk University stand in the field of research infrastructures compared to the world? This lecture will tell you about that too.

#### Target group

This training activity is intended primarily for PhD students, but can be interesting also for postdocs or junior/senior researchers.

#### Learning objectives

By the end of this course, participants will learn the role and significance of research infrastructures in advancing scientific collaboration and efficiency. They will analyze the Czech Republic’s and Masaryk University’s standings in the global context and evaluate the economic and practical benefits of shared research resources.

title: The Fall of an Empire or the Rise of Europe? (Autum 2024)
description:
#### Learning objectives

In the traditional historiographical narrative, the arrival of the “barbarians” corresponds to the end of the greatest civilization of the antique Mediterranean: the Roman Empire. But was the situation so simple? Who were these “barbarians”? And did the Empire really collapse or was it rather transformed? The goal of this course is to focus on the artistic, visual, material, and performative cultures that coexisted in this extraordinary moment of history. To reach this objective, we will firstly focus on the prejudices constructed from the Renaissance to our days about what was commonly considered as the “Dark Ages”. Secondly, we will be investigating the role of medias in the transformations of visual history: from sculptures to “bidimensional” images, from roll to codex, from the illusive image to the iconic one. Third, we will analyze the role played by the meeting of cultures – constitutive for the investigated period – in the birth of the “Middle Ages”.

This course is taught by the Department of Art History at Masaryk University. 

At the end of the course participants will:
- be able to orientate himself in the visual and material cultures of the Late Antique to Early Medieval world;
- understand the tools and the importance of visual culture within social and historical phenomena;
- fall in love with art history!

title: Digital competence development course (Autumn 2024)
description:
#### Learning objectives
The aim of the course is to show the broader context of digital competences. We start from DigComp, which defines five areas of competence within which each citizen should develop. It tries to show how individual competences influence and change the information society and what impact their development or absence can have. At the same time, they also seek to deepen them in practice.

At the end of the course participants will:
- Define and critically reflect digital competences
- Work alone, even in a team with a European Reference Framework
- Understand the relationship of the information society and digital competences
- Engage in the development of digital competencies in specific teams
- Use appropriate tools for each competence area
- Safely use online communication tools to reflect data leaks and misuse issues
- Set your personal balance between work and study, between technology and nature. Students will be able to understand basic concepts of copyright.
- Students will have the basic ability to work with information and understand why information is related to power.

title: French for beginners A1
description:
This course provides the opportunity to discover the French language and culture.

Objectives
- Acquire basic knowledge of French
- Be able to interact in a simple way with a speaker who speaks slowly.
- Be able to ask and answer simple questions relating to the learner and his/her immediate environment.
- be able to understand simple statements and use everyday expressions
- be able to write short, simple texts such as postcards.

Teaching approach :
- The approach, based on the CEFR, is based on active teaching. Oral and written communication are approached through a variety of situations and activities, in order to facilitate the acquisition of basic skills and support learners' motivation, in a distance learning context. 
- The lexicon and grammar points necessary for everyday communication situations are studied. The cultural and intercultural dimensions involved in language learning are also addressed in the course.
- Learners are asked to do some personal work between two sessions in order to reinforce their language skills.
prerequisites: Absolute beginners in French. All levels of study welcome.

title: Introduction to Media Studies 2024
description: This  course  intends  to  give  an  overall  view  of  the  theoretical  frameworks  to  media  studies.  The  lecture  is organized around three major didactic issues that follow the evolution and concepts of mass communication through  the  genre  of  media  to  its  reception.  The  first phase  of  the  course introduces  the  historical development  of  mass  communications,  its  important  concepts  and  models  from  the  perspective  of  media theory and social theory. The second unit introduces the audience to the social and formal issues of media content, focusing on media genres. Finally, we review the traditions and experiences of audience theory and audience research, as well as the characteristics of audience formation, with a particular focus on fan cultures. Learning  outcomes:  by  studying  this  module,  students  acquire  knowledge  about media  history,  media technology,  media  theories,  media  content and  consumption.  They  will  learn  about  the  multiplicity  of theories  and  approaches  to media in  the  framework  of  human  and  social  sciences.  They  acquire a  critical attitude  towards  media  culture  and  media  society  as  well  as  some  practical knowledge about  potential beneficial and harmful effects of media contents.\n
prerequisites: There is no pre-requisite for the course, however, a basic interest in current media affairs is recommended. Assessment: active participation and homework (40%);1x1200wd Mid Term Essay (25%); 1x1800wd End Term Essay (35%). All documents are presented in a portfolio format at the end of the semester. \n
